xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This document, CIS Oracle MySQL Enterprise Edition 5.7 Benchmark, provides prescriptive guidance for establishing a secure configuration posture for MySQL Enterprise Edition 5.7. To obtain the latest version of this guide, please visit http://benchmarks.cisecurity.org . xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations related to the Operating System on which the MySQL database server is running.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Place Databases on Non-System Partitions

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: It is generally accepted that host operating systems should include different filesystem partitions for different purposes. One set of filesystems is typically called system partitions, and these are generally reserved for host system/application operation. The other set of filesystems is typically called "non-system partitions", and such locations are generally reserved for storing data.

controls:safeguard.title: Segment Data Processing and Storage Based on Sensitivity
Physically or Logically Segregate High Risk Applications

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Moving the database off the system partition will reduce the probability of denial of service caused by exhaustion of available disk space to the operating system.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following steps to remediate this setting for the datadir :

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: Backup the database.
Choose a non-system partition new location for MySQL data.
Stop mysqld using a command like: service mysql stop .

Copy the data using a command like: cp -rp
<datadir Value> <new location>
.
Set the datadir location to the new location in the MySQL configuration file.

Start mysqld using a command like: service mysql start
Note: On some Linux distributions you may need to additionally modify apparmor settings. For example, on a Ubuntu 14.04.1 system edit the file /etc/apparmor.d/usr.sbin.mysqld so that the datadir access is appropriate. The original might look like this: # Allow data dir access /var/lib/mysql/ r, /var/lib/mysql/** rwk,
Alter those two paths to be the new location you chose above. For example, if that new location were /media/mysql , then the /etc/apparmor.d/usr.sbin.mysqld file should include something like this: # Allow data dir access /media/mysql/ r, /media/mysql/** rwk,

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

Moving database files and directories to a non-system partition may be difficult depending on whether there was only a single partition when the operating system was set up and whether there are additional non-system partitions available.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Use Dedicated Least Privileged Account for MySQL Daemon/Service

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: As with any service installed on a host, it can be provided with its own user context. Providing a dedicated user to the service provides the ability to precisely constrain the service within the larger host context.

notes:notes.xhtml:p: The root user may be used to start the MySQL service on Linux/UNIX, but then it must be configured to drop privileges by specifying a service specific user in the my.cnf or my.ini file.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Utilizing a least privilege account for MySQL to execute as needed may reduce the impact of a MySQL-born vulnerability. A restricted account will be unable to access resources unrelated to MySQL, such as operating system configurations.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Create a user which is only used for running MySQL and directly related processes. This user must not have administrative rights to the system. Additionally, it's best to avoid providing shell access to such an account.
Shell access can be removed using the following command at a terminal prompt:

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Disable MySQL Command History

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: On Linux/UNIX, the MySQL client and MySQL Shell log statements executed interactively to a history file. The default MySQL Client file is named .mysql_history in the user's home directory. The files are split by language and named history.sql , history.js and history.py . Most interactive commands run in the MySQL client application are saved to a history file. The MySQL command history should be disabled. By default, the MySQL Shell does not save history between sessions.

controls:safeguard.title: Securely Dispose of Data
Remove Sensitive Data or Systems Not Regularly Accessed by Organization

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Disabling the MySQL Client and MySQL Shell command history reduces the probability of exposing sensitive information, such as passwords, encryption keys, or other sensitive data or information.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following steps to remediate this setting:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: Remove .mysql_history if it exists.

Use either of the techniques below to prevent it from being created again:
Set the MYSQL_HISTFILE environment variable to /dev/null. This will need to be placed in the shell's startup script.
Create $HOME/.mysql_history as a symbolic to /dev/null . > ln -s /dev/null $HOME/.mysql_history

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Another way to prevent history from being recorded is to use --batch option.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Verify That the MYSQL_PWD Environment Variable Is Not In Use

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: MySQL can read a default database password from an environment variable called MYSQL_PWD . Avoiding use of this environment variable can better safeguard the confidentiality of MySQL credentials.

controls:safeguard.title: Encrypt Sensitive Data at Rest
Encrypt or Hash all Authentication Credentials

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Using the MYSQL_PWD environment variable implies MySQL credentials are stored as clear text.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Check which users and/or scripts are setting MYSQL_PWD and change them to use a more secure method.
For unattended logins you should consider:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: MySQL Configuration Editor
Different authentication methods (e.g., X509 certificate verification)
Use MySQL Enterprise LDAP plugin with Kerberos or SASL tokens.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure Interactive Login is Disabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: When created, the MySQL user may have interactive access to the operating system, which means that the MySQL user could login to the host as any other user would.

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Administrator Privileges to Dedicated Administrator Accounts
Ensure the Use of Dedicated Administrative Accounts

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Preventing the MySQL user from logging in interactively may reduce the impact of a compromised MySQL account. There is also more accountability, as accessing the operating system where the MySQL server lies will require the user's own account. Interactive access by the MySQL user is unnecessary and should be disabled.

This setting will prevent the MySQL administrator from interactively logging into the operating system using the MySQL user. Instead, the administrator will need to log in using one's own account.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Verify That 'MYSQL_PWD' is Not Set in Users' Profiles

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: MySQL can read a default database password from an environment variable called MYSQL_PWD .

controls:safeguard.title: Encrypt Sensitive Data at Rest
Encrypt or Hash all Authentication Credentials

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The use of the MYSQL_PWD environment variable implies the clear text storage of MySQL credentials. Avoiding this may increase assurance that the confidentiality of MySQL credentials is preserved.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Check which users and/or scripts are setting MYSQL_PWD and change them to use a more secure method.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains important considerations when deploying MySQL services to your production network and defining the configuration. The recommendations made herein are not scored from a benchmark perspective and generally align with best current practices as conveyed in most control frameworks.

An important consideration is related to the configuration options via the MySQL configuration file (e.g., my.cnf ) and placing options under the proper section of [mysqld] . Options placed in the my.cnf configuration file should not prefix with a double dash ( -- ). On Linux systems, my.cnf is located in the /etc/ directory.
Finally, configuration options can also be placed on the command line by modifying the MySQL startup script. The startup script is system dependent and based on your operating system.
This section contains recommendations related to backup and recovery

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Backup Policy in Place

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: A backup policy should be in place.

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Automated Backups

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Backing up MySQL databases, including mysql , will help ensure the availability of data in the event of an incident. Without backups it might be hard to recover from an incident.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Create a backup policy and backup schedule.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Verify Backups are Good

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Backups should be validated on a regular basis.

controls:safeguard.title: Test Data Recovery
Test Data on Backup Media

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Verifying that backups are occurring appropriately will help ensure the availability of data in the event of an incident. Without a well-tested backup it might be hard to recover from an incident if the backup procedure contains errors or doesn't include all required data.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Implement regular backup checks and document each check.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Secure Backup Credentials

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: A database user with the least amount of privileges required to perform backup is needed for backup. The credentials for this user should be protected. The password, certificate and any other credentials should be protected.

controls:safeguard.title: Configure Data Access Control Lists
Protect Recovery Data
Ensure Protection of Backups

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: When the backup credentials are not properly secured then they might be abused to gain access to the server. The backup user needs an account with many privileges, so the attacker can gain (almost) complete access to the server.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Change file permissions.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: The Backups Should be Properly Secured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The backup files will contain all data in the databases. Filesystem permissions and/or encryption should be used to prevent unauthorized users from gaining access to the backups.

controls:safeguard.title: Protect Recovery Data
Ensure Protection of Backups

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Backups should be considered sensitive information. If an unauthorized user can access backups, then they have access to all data in the database. This is true for unencrypted backups and for encrypted backups if the encryption key is stored along with the backup.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Implement encryption, properly restrict filesystem permissions, protect and backup encryption keys.
For example, if you run MySQL Enterprise Backup include --encrypt-password
Mysqlbackup includes not just the database data, but also provides for secure backup of keys, and support for secured archival storage.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Point-in-Time Recovery

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: With binlogs it is possible to implement point-in-time recovery. This makes it possible to restore the changes between the last full backup and the point-in-time.

Enabling binlogs is not sufficient. The binlogs need to be backed up to separate media. The restore procedure should be created and tested. The data in the binlog files may contain sensitive information which needs be stored in the proper location with restrictive permissions and may require encryption.

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Automated Backups
Perform Complete System Backups

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Using binlogs can reduce the amount of information lost when recovering from a backup.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Enable binlogs and create and test a restore procedure.
Impact:
Binlogs can grow quite large and take up a large amount of space so auto remove needs to be put into place.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Disaster Recovery (DR) Plan

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: A disaster recovery plan should be created.
MySQL Cluster (group replication), MySQL Replica Sets (asynchronous replication) or both may be used.

A slave in a different data center and offsite backups may be used. There should be information regarding the Recovery Time Objective (RTO), i.e., how long recovery will take, and if the recovery site has the same capacity. Additionally, delayed replicas can be a valuable part of a DR plan. Network (default) and at rest encryption should be used to protect data.

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain a Data Recovery Process

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: A disaster recovery strategy should be planned and formalized. Without a well tested disaster recovery plan it might not be possible to recover in time.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Create a disaster recovery plan

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Backup of Configuration and Related Files

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: It is important to include configuration, log, key, certificates, and customized files in backups.

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Automated Backups
Perform Complete System Backups

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Including all configuration, log, key, certificates, and customized files in any backup will ensure the backup can fully restore an instance.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Add any omitted files to the backup.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Dedicate the Machine Running MySQL

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: It is recommended that MySQL Server software be installed on a dedicated server. This architectural consideration affords flexibility in that the database server can be placed on a separate zone allowing access only from particular hosts and over particular protocols.

controls:safeguard.title: Segment Data Processing and Storage Based on Sensitivity
Physically or Logically Segregate High Risk Applications

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The attack surface is reduced on a server with only the underlying operating system, MySQL server software, and any security or operational tooling that may be additionally installed. A smaller attack surface reduces the probability of the data within MySQL being compromised.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Remove excess applications or services and/or remove unnecessary roles from the underlying operating system.
Impact:
Care must be taken to ensure that applications or services that are required for proper operation of the operating system are not removed.
Custom applications may need to be modified to accommodate database connections over the network rather than on the use (e.g., using TCP/IP connections).
Additional hardware and operating system licenses may be required to make the architectural change.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Do Not Specify Passwords in the Command Line

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: When a command is executed on the command line, for example mysql -u admin -p password , the password may be visible in the user's shell/command history or in the process list.

controls:safeguard.title: Encrypt Sensitive Data in Transit
Encrypt or Hash all Authentication Credentials

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If the password is visible in the process list or user's shell/command history, an attacker will be able to access the MySQL database using the stolen credentials.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Use -p without password and then enter the password when prompted, use a properly secured .my.cnf file, or store authentication information in encrypted format in .mylogin.cnf .
Impact:
Depending on the remediation chosen, additional steps may need to be undertaken like:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Entering a password when prompted.
Ensuring the file permissions on .my.cnf is restricted yet accessible by the user.
Using mysql_config_editor to encrypt the authentication credentials in .mylogin.cnf .

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Additionally, not all scripts/applications may be able to use .mylogin.cnf .

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Do Not Reuse Usernames

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Database user accounts should not be reused for multiple applications or users.

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain an Inventory of Accounts
Ensure the Use of Dedicated Administrative Accounts

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Utilizing unique database accounts across applications will reduce the impact of a compromised MySQL account. If a user is reused, then a compromise of this user will compromise multiple parts of the system and/or application.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Add/Remove users so that each user is only used for one specific purpose.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure Non-Default, Unique Cryptographic Material is in Use

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The cryptographic material used by MySQL, such as digital certificates and encryption keys, should be used only for MySQL and only for one instance. Default cryptographic material should not be used since it is not unique to the instance.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If a cryptographic material is used on multiple MySQL instances and/or systems then a compromise of one may lead to the compromise of the network traffic of all servers which use the same cryptographic material. If an attacker gains access to shared cryptographic material, including default material, the attacker can reuse that material to impersonate the MySQL server or otherwise compromise its operations.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Generate new certificates, keys, and other cryptographic material as needed for each affected MySQL instance.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Passwords that are too complex in nature make it harder for users to remember, leading to bad practices. In general, longer passwords are better (harder to crack), but a forced password length requirement can cause user behavior that is predictable and undesirable. Having a reasonable minimum length with no maximum character limit increases the resulting average password length used and thus increases the security of that password.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This option causes mysqld to start without using the privilege system.

controls:safeguard.title: Configure Data Access Control Lists
Protect Information through Access Control Lists

notes:notes.xhtml:p: This option has no SHOW VARIABLES counterpart.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If this option is used, all clients of the affected server will have unrestricted access to all databases.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following to establish the recommended state:

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure Symbolic Links are Disabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The symbolic-links and skip-symbolic-links options for MySQL determine whether symbolic link support is available. When use of symbolic links is enabled, they have different effects depending on the host platform. When symbolic links are disabled, then symbolic links stored in files or entries in tables are not used by the database.

controls:safeguard.title: Apply Secure Design Principles in Application Architectures

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Prevents symbolic links from being used for database files. This is especially important when MySQL is executing as root as arbitrary files may be overwritten. The symbolic-links option might allow someone to direct actions by the MySQL server to other files and/or directories.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following actions to remediate this setting:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Open the MySQL configuration file ( my.cnf )
Locate skip_symbolic_links in the configuration
Set the skip_symbolic_links to YES

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Note: If skip_symbolic_links does not exist, add it to the configuration file in the mysqld section.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure the 'daemon_memcached' Plugin is Disabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The InnoDB memcached Plugin allows users to access data stored in InnoDB with the memcached protocol.

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: By default, the plugin doesn't do authentication, which means that anyone with access to the TCP/IP port of the plugin can access and modify the data. However, not all data is exposed by default.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, issue the following command in the MySQL command-line client:
This uninstalls the memcached plugin from the MySQL server.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure the 'secure_file_priv' is Configured Correctly

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The secure_file_priv option restricts to paths used by LOAD DATA INFILE or SELECT local_file . It is recommended that this option be set to a file system location that contains only resources expected to be loaded by MySQL. Even better, if data import/export using LOAD DATA INFILE or SELECT local_file is not used, the functionality should be disabled entirely by setting --secure-file-priv to NULL .

controls:safeguard.title: Configure Data Access Control Lists

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting secure_file_priv reduces an attacker's ability to read sensitive files off the affected server via a SQL injection vulnerability.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: If you are not going to use this feature, remove secure_file_priv from the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file and restart the MySQL service.
If you need this feature add the following line to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file and restart the MySQL service:
Impact:
Solutions that rely on loading data from various sub-directories may be negatively impacted by this change. Consider consolidating load directories under a common parent directory.

The server checks the value of secure_file_priv at startup and writes a warning to the error log if the value is insecure. A non-NULL value is considered insecure if it is empty, or the value is the data directory or a subdirectory of it, or a directory that is accessible by all users.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'sql_mode' Contains 'STRICT_ALL_TABLES'

controls:safeguard.title: Apply Secure Design Principles in Application Architectures

notes:notes.xhtml:p: The sql_mode is a set and might contain more elements than just STRICT_ALL_TABLES .
There is a global sql_mode and a per session sql_mode . The per session sql_mode is based on the global sql_mode on initialization and might be changed by the application.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Without strict mode the server tries to proceed with the action when an error might have been a more secure choice. For example, by default MySQL will truncate data if it does not fit in a field, which can lead to unknown behavior, or be leveraged by an attacker to circumvent data validation.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Set STRICT_ALL_TABLES to the sql_mode in the server's global configuration, for example:
Impact:
Applications relying on the MySQL database should be aware that STRICT_ALL_TABLES is in use, such that error conditions are handled appropriately.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Use MySQL TDE for At-Rest Data Encryption

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) at-rest encryption protects your critical data by enabling data-at-rest encryption in the database. It protects the privacy of your information, prevents data breaches and helps meet regulatory requirements.

controls:safeguard.title: Encrypt Sensitive Data at Rest
Encrypt Sensitive Information at Rest

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: File system based encryption does a good job of protecting against data theft on devices unable to limit physical access. It does not, however, protect against users who have or gain access to the operating system, backups, over the network copies, etc. Encrypting data from mysqld adds an additional layer of data protection.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations about user privileges.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure Only Administrative Users Have Full Database Access

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The mysql.user , mysql.db , and other mysql tables ending in _priv list a variety of privileges that can be granted (or denied) to MySQL users. Some of the privileges of concern include: Select_priv , Insert_priv , Update_priv , Delete_priv , Drop_priv , and so on. Typically, these privileges should not be available to every MySQL user and often are reserved for administrative use only. The information_schema.user_privileges provides a consolidated view of all user privileges.

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Administrator Privileges to Dedicated Administrator Accounts
Maintain Inventory of Administrative Accounts
Protect Information through Access Control Lists

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Consideration should be made for which privileges are required by each user requiring interactive database access.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Limiting the accessibility of the mysql database will protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the data housed within MySQL. A user which has direct access to mysql.* might view password hashes, change permissions, or alter or destroy information intentionally or unintentionally.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following actions to remediate this setting:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: Enumerate non-administrative users resulting from the audit procedure.
For each non-administrative user, use the REVOKE statement to remove privileges as appropriate.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'FILE' is Not Granted to Non-Administrative Users

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The FILE privilege is used to allow or disallow a user from reading and writing files on the server host. Any user with the FILE right granted has the ability to:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Read files from the local file system that are readable by the MySQL server (this includes world-readable files).
Write files to the local file system where the MySQL server has write access.

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Administrator Privileges to Dedicated Administrator Accounts
Protect Information through Access Control Lists

notes:notes.xhtml:p: See also: secure_file_priv system settings.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The FILE right allows MySQL users to read files from disk and to write files to disk. This may be leveraged by an attacker to further compromise MySQL. It should be noted that the MySQL server should not overwrite existing files.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following steps to remediate this setting:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: Enumerate the non-administrative users found in the result set of the audit procedure.

For each user, issue the following SQL statement (replace <user>
with the non-administrative user): REVOKE FILE ON *.* FROM '<user>';

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'PROCESS' is Not Granted to Non-Administrative Users

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The PROCESS privilege found in the mysql.user table determines whether a given user can see statement execution information for all sessions.

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Administrator Privileges to Dedicated Administrator Accounts
Protect Information through Access Control Lists

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The PROCESS privilege allows principals to view currently executing MySQL statements beyond their own, including statements used to manage passwords. This may be leveraged by an attacker to compromise MySQL or to gain access to potentially sensitive data.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following steps to remediate this setting:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: Enumerate the non-administrative users found in the result set of the audit procedure

For each user, issue the following SQL statement (replace <user>
with the non-administrative user): REVOKE PROCESS ON *.* FROM '<user>';

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users denied the PROCESS privilege may also be denied use of SHOW ENGINE .

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'SUPER' is Not Granted to Non-Administrative Users

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The SUPER privilege is a powerful and far-reaching privilege and should not be granted lightly.

The SUPER privilege shown in the INFORMATION_SCHEMA.USER_PRIVILEGES table governs the use of a variety of MySQL features. These features include, CHANGE MASTER TO , KILL , mysqladmin kill option, PURGE BINARY LOGS , SET GLOBAL , mysqladmin debug option, logging control, and more.

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Administrator Privileges to Dedicated Administrator Accounts
Protect Information through Access Control Lists

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The SUPER privilege allows principals to perform many actions, including view and terminate currently executing MySQL statements (including statements used to manage passwords). This privilege also provides the ability to configure MySQL, such as enable/disable logging, alter data, disable/enable features. Limiting the accounts that have the SUPER privilege reduces the chances that an attacker can exploit these capabilities.
It is more secure to migrate administrative users off SUPER and instead assign the specific and minimal set of mysql Dynamic Privileges needed to perform their tasks.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following steps to remediate this setting:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: Enumerate the non-administrative users found in the result set of the audit procedure

For each user, issue the following SQL statement (replace <user>
with the non-administrative user): REVOKE SUPER ON *.* FROM '<user>';
Next minimize administrator rights
Assess the minimal set of Dynamic Permissions needed by a user to perform their duties.
For each user assign the appropriate Dynamic Permission and then revoke that <user>
SUPER capability.
For example, if administrator 'u1'@'localhost' requires SUPER for binary log purging and system variable modification, these statements make the required changes to the account thus limiting rights to what is needed: GRANT BINLOG_ADMIN, SYSTEM_VARIABLES_ADMIN ON *.* TO 'u1'@'localhost'; REVOKE SUPER ON *.* FROM 'u1'@'localhost';

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
When the SUPER privilege is denied to a given user, that user will be unable to take advantage of certain capabilities, such as certain mysqladmin options.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'SHUTDOWN' is Not Granted to Non-Administrative Users

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The SHUTDOWN privilege simply enables use of the shutdown option to the mysqladmin command, which allows a user with the SHUTDOWN privilege the ability to shut down the MySQL server.

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Administrator Privileges to Dedicated Administrator Accounts
Protect Information through Access Control Lists

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The SHUTDOWN privilege allows principals to shutdown MySQL. This may be leveraged by an attacker to negatively impact the availability of MySQL.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following steps to remediate this setting:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: Enumerate the non-administrative users found in the result set of the audit procedure.

For each user, issue the following SQL statement (replace <user>
with the non-administrative user): REVOKE SHUTDOWN ON *.* FROM '<user>';

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'CREATE USER' is Not Granted to Non-Administrative Users

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The CREATE USER privilege governs the right of a given user to add or remove users, change existing users' names, or revoke existing users' privileges.

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Administrator Privileges to Dedicated Administrator Accounts
Protect Information through Access Control Lists

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Reducing the number of users granted the CREATE USER right minimizes the number of users able to add/drop users, alter existing users' names, and manipulate existing users' privileges.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following steps to remediate this setting:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: Enumerate the non-administrative users found in the result set of the audit procedure

For each user, issue the following SQL statement (replace <user>
with the non-administrative user): REVOKE CREATE USER ON *.* FROM '<user>';

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users that are denied the CREATE USER privilege will not only be unable to create a user, but they may be unable to drop a user, rename a user, or otherwise revoke a given user's privileges.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'GRANT OPTION' is Not Granted to Non-Administrative Users

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The GRANT OPTION privilege exists in different contexts ( mysql.user , mysql.db ) for the purpose of governing the ability of a privileged user to manipulate the privileges of other users.

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Administrator Privileges to Dedicated Administrator Accounts
Protect Information through Access Control Lists

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The GRANT OPTION privilege allows a principal to grant other principals additional privileges. This may be used by an attacker to compromise MySQL.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following steps to remediate this setting:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: Enumerate the non-administrative users found in the result sets of the audit procedure

For each user, issue the following SQL statement (replace <user>
with the non-administrative user): REVOKE GRANT OPTION ON *.* FROM <user>;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'REPLICATION SLAVE' is Not Granted to Non-Administrative Users

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The REPLICATION SLAVE privilege governs whether a given user (in the context of the source server) can request updates that have been made on the source server.

controls:safeguard.title: Configure Data Access Control Lists
Protect Information through Access Control Lists

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The REPLICATION SLAVE privilege allows a principal to fetch binlog files containing all data changing statements and/or changes to table data from the source. This may be used by an attacker to read/fetch sensitive data from MySQL.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following steps to remediate this setting:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: Enumerate the non-replica users found in the result set of the audit procedure

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure DML/DDL Grants are Limited to Specific Databases and Users

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: DML/DDL includes the set of privileges used to modify or create data structures. This includes INSERT , SELECT , UPDATE , DELETE , DROP , CREATE , and ALTER privileges.

controls:safeguard.title: Configure Data Access Control Lists
Protect Information through Access Control Lists

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: INSERT , SELECT , UPDATE , DELETE , DROP , CREATE , and ALTER are powerful privileges in any database. Such privileges should be limited only to those users requiring such rights. By limiting the users with these rights and ensuring that they are limited to specific databases, the attack surface of the database is reduced.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following steps to remediate this setting:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: Enumerate the unauthorized users, hosts, and databases returned in the result set of the audit procedure

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Securely Define Stored Procedures and Functions DEFINER and INVOKER

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Stored procedure and stored function declarations include a definition of permissions which can be used to escalate permissions. It's important to inspect these settings to ensure they do not unnecessarily escalate privileges.

controls:safeguard.title: Apply Secure Design Principles in Application Architectures
Protect Information through Access Control Lists

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: A stored procedure or function that improperly escalates privileges may provide unintended access rights which can be improperly used.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Drop and recreate stored procedures and functions using proper DEFINER and INVOKER settings, or other code changes.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section provides guidance with respect to MySQL's logging behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'log_error' is configured correctly

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The error log contains information about events such as mysqld starting and stopping, when a table needs to be checked or repaired, and, depending on the host operating system, stack traces when mysqld fails.

controls:safeguard.title: Collect Audit Logs
Activate audit logging

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Enabling error logging can increase the ability to detect malicious attempts against MySQL, and other critical messages. For example, if the error log is not enabled then a connection error could go unnoticed.

When configured to stderr MySQL will send log data to the console. Logging to the console is useful, but remember it is ephemeral. This is not recommended due to the fact that logging to console does not provide a means to force restricted access via permissions strictly to MySQL and dedicated MySQL audit accounts. This may compromise the confidentiality of the MySQL log data. Furthermore use caution if co-mingling log data from multiple sources as that can complicate log inspection. Additionally from a security auditing perspective, its difficult and error prone to verify logging is correct using stderr or redirected stderr .

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following actions to remediate this setting:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: Set the log-error option to the path for the error log.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure Log Files are Stored on a Non-System Partition

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: MySQL log files can be set in the MySQL configuration to exist anywhere on the filesystem. It is common practice to ensure that the system filesystem is left uncluttered by application logs. System filesystems include the root ( / ), /var , or /usr .

controls:safeguard.title: Ensure Adequate Audit Log Storage
Ensure adequate storage for logs

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Moving the MySQL logs off the system partition will reduce the probability of denial of service via the exhaustion of available disk space to the operating system.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following actions to remediate this setting:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: Open the MySQL configuration file ( my.cnf )
Locate the log-bin entry and set it to a file not on root ( / ), /var , or /usr

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'log_error_verbosity' is Set to '2'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The log_error_verbosity system variable, set to 2 by default, specifies the verbosity of events sent to the MySQL error log. A value of 2 enables logging of error and warning messages, a value of 3 also includes informational logging, a value of 1 logs only errors.

controls:safeguard.title: Collect Detailed Audit Logs
Enable Detailed Logging

notes:notes.xhtml:p: log_warnings has been deprecated as of MySQL 5.7.2. Setting log_warnings will also cause log_error_verbosity to be set.The variable scope for log_warnings is global.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This might help to detect malicious behavior by logging communication errors and aborted connections.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following actions to remediate this setting:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Open the MySQL configuration file ( my.cnf )
Ensure the following line is found in the mysqld section log_error_verbosity = 2

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'log-raw' is Set to 'OFF'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The log-raw MySQL option determines whether passwords are rewritten by the server so as not to appear in log files as plain text. If log-raw is enabled, then passwords are written to the various log files ( general query log , slow query log , and binary log ) in plain text.

controls:safeguard.title: Securely Dispose of Data
Remove Sensitive Data or Systems Not Regularly Accessed by Organization

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: With raw logging of passwords enabled someone with access to the log files might see plain text passwords.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following actions to remediate this setting:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Open the MySQL configuration file ( my.cnf )
Find the log-raw entry and set it as follows log-raw = OFF

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure Audit Filters Capture Connection Attempts

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The functions audit_log_filter_set_filter() and audit_log_filter_set_user() are used to define rules for auditing. With this feature you can easily audit successful and/or failed connection events and write to the audit log file.

controls:safeguard.title: Collect Detailed Audit Logs

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Prior legacy modes of defining audit filters, although simple to use, were not specific enough to define precise auditing rules - and thus required too much storage - resulting in "over" auditing. Additionally MySQL audit filters can not only log events but act as firewall rules by using an abort() definition in a filter.
See:

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The audit_log_filter_set_filter function which defines auditing filters. The users for which filter(s) apply is defined by audit_log_filter_set_user . One or more filters can be created to log connections success and/or failure.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this configuration setting, execute one of the following SQL statements:
Log All connections Successful and Failed:
Or Log Only Failed Connections:
Impact:
If the audit rule and application of the rule to targeted or all users is not properly configured, it will not log failed connections, successful connections or any other connection related events.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure ALL Events are Audited

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This filter defines all events to be written to the audit log.

controls:safeguard.title: Require MFA for Externally-Exposed Applications
Collect Detailed Audit Logs

notes:notes.xhtml:p: If an appropriate filter and binding of the filter to users is not in place then audit events related to all events won't be written to the audit log file.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This filter to log all, and binding to all, users must be set to ensure all event information is written to the audit log.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Create Log All Filter:
Apply to all logins:
Impact:
Logging all events can result in very large audit files. In the case where the database is extremely active it may be more appropriate to be more selective when defining audit filters.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Set audit_log_strategy to SYNCHRONOUS or SEMISYNCRONOUS

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The audit_log_strategy must be set to SYNCHRONOUS or SEMISYNCHRONOUS

controls:safeguard.title: Collect Detailed Audit Logs

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Also consider the load strategy.
For example, most secure is to set --audit-log=FORCE_PLUS_PERMANENT
This tells the server to load the plugin and prevent it from being removed while the server is running.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This setting controls how information is written to the audit log. It can be set to SYNCHRONOUS to make it fully durable or other settings which are less durable but have less performance overhead.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this configuration:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: Open the MySQL configuration file ( my.cnf )
Navigate to the mysqld section of the configuration file

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is set to PERFORMANCE or ASYNCHRONOUS audit events might be lost in case of a crash or when the server somehow can't write to the audit log file.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure the Audit Plugin Can't be Unloaded

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Set audit_log to FORCE_PLUS_PERMANENT

controls:safeguard.title: Collect Audit Logs
Activate audit logging

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This disables unloading of the plugin.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, follow these steps:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: Open the MySQL configuration file ( my.cnf )
Ensure the following line is found in the mysqld section audit_log = 'FORCE_PLUS_PERMANENT'

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If someone can unload the plugin it would be possible to perform actions on the database without audit events being logged to the audit log. If the audit log plugin can be unloaded the audit log can be temporarily or permanently disabled.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains configuration recommendations that pertain to the authentication mechanisms of MySQL.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure default_authentication_plugin is Set to a Secure Option

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The default-authentication-plugin system variable governs two things:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Authentication plugin used by a new user account if a plugin is not specified explicitly through CREATE USER statement
Initial authentication data payload generated by server in case of a new connection.

controls:safeguard.title: Encrypt Sensitive Data at Rest
Encrypt or Hash all Authentication Credentials

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: MySQL Native Authentication relies on the Secure Hash Algorithm 1 (SHA1) algorithm and the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) has suggested to stop using it.
The MySQL Native Authentication plugin leverages this weak hashing algorithm that can be quickly brute forced.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Configure mysql to default to the sha256_password plugin.
Require sha256_password plugin to be used by default for new accounts.
Edit my.cnf , in the section [mysqld] add:
Determine if any users are using mysql_native_password .
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: select host, user, plugin from mysql.user;
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Migrate these users from mysql_native_password .
xhtml:p.xhtml:code:
ALTER USER user
IDENTIFIED WITH sha256_password IDENTIFIED BY RANDOM PASSWORD PASSWORD EXPIRE;
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Provide users the random password value through a secure mechanism - on next login they will be forced to change the password.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure Passwords are Not Stored in the Global Configuration

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The [client] section of the MySQL configuration file allows setting a user and password to be used. Verify the password option is not used in the global configuration file ( my.cnf ).

controls:safeguard.title: Encrypt Sensitive Data at Rest
Encrypt or Hash all Authentication Credentials

notes:notes.xhtml:p: There must not be a password in any of the sections of the global configuration. The global configuration is by default readable for all users on the system. This is needed for global defaults (prompt, port, socket, etc.). If a password is present in this file then all users on the system may be able to access it.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Using the password parameter may negatively impact the confidentiality of the user's password.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Use the mysql_config_editor to store authentication credentials in .mylogin.cnf in encrypted form.
If not possible, use the user-specific options file, .my.cnf. , and restricting file access permissions to the user identity.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'sql_mode' Contains 'NO_AUTO_CREATE_USER'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: NO_AUTO_CREATE_USER is an option for sql_mode that prevents a GRANT statement from automatically creating a user when authentication information is not provided.

controls:safeguard.title: Apply Secure Design Principles in Application Architectures

notes:notes.xhtml:p: NO_AUTO_CREATE_USER is deprecated and it is included in the default SQL mode. The documentation for this mode states:

> Previously, before NO_AUTO_CREATE_USER was deprecated, one reason not to enable it was that it was not replication safe. Now it can be enabled and replication-safe user management performed with CREATE USER IF NOT EXISTS, DROP USER IF EXISTS, and ALTER USER IF EXISTS rather than GRANT. These statements enable safe replication when replicas may have different grants than those on the source.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Blank passwords negate the benefits provided by authentication mechanisms. Without this setting an administrative user might accidentally create a user without a password.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following actions to remediate this setting:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: Open the MySQL configuration file ( my.cnf )
Find the sql_mode setting in the [mysqld] area
Add the NO_AUTO_CREATE_USER to the sql_mode setting

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure Passwords are Set for All MySQL Accounts

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Blank passwords allow a user to login without using a password.

controls:safeguard.title: Use Unique Passwords
Use Unique Passwords

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Without a password only knowing the username and the list of allowed hosts will allow someone to connect to the server and assume the identity of the user. This, in effect, bypasses authentication mechanisms.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: For each row returned from the audit procedure, reset the password for the given user using the following statement (as an example):
xhtml:p.xhtml:code:
ALTER USER
<user>@<host> IDENTIFIED BY RANDOM PASSWORD PASSWORD EXPIRE;
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: This resets the password temporarily to a RANDOM string and returns that temporary password as a result. The user can then use this temporary password to login and is forced to set the password to one of their choosing upon login.

Note: Replace <user>
, <host>
with appropriate values.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Set 'default_password_lifetime' to Require a Yearly Password Change

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Password expiry provides passwords with a time bounded lifetime.

controls:safeguard.title: Disable Dormant Accounts
Ensure All Accounts Have An Expiration Date

More importantly, when events occur that could compromise password security account passwords should be expired immediately.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure Password Complexity Policies are in Place

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Password complexity includes password characteristics such as length, case, numerical, and character sets.

controls:safeguard.title: Use Unique Passwords
Use Unique Passwords

notes:notes.xhtml:p: The system variable validate_password_check_user_name is exposed by validate_password starting with MySQL 5.7.15.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Complex passwords help mitigate dictionary, brute forcing, and other password attacks. This recommendation prevents users from choosing weak passwords which can easily be guessed.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure No Anonymous Accounts Exist

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Anonymous accounts are users with empty usernames (''). Anonymous accounts have no passwords, so anyone can use them to connect to the MySQL server.

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain an Inventory of Accounts
Maintain an Inventory of Accounts

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Using the standard installation script, mysql_install_db , it will create two anonymous accounts: one for the host localhost and the other for the network interface's IP address.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Removing anonymous accounts will help ensure that only identified and trusted principals are capable of interacting with MySQL.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following actions to remediate this setting:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: Enumerate the anonymous users returned from executing the audit procedure.
For each anonymous user, DROP or assign them a name.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Note: As an alternative, you may execute the mysql_secure_installation utility.
Impact:
Any applications relying on anonymous database access will be adversely affected by this change.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure Replication Traffic Is Secured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The replication traffic between servers should be secured. Security measures should include ensuring the confidentiality and integrity of the traffic, and performing mutual authentication between the servers before performing replication.

controls:safeguard.title: Encrypt Sensitive Data in Transit
Encrypt All Sensitive Information in Transit

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The replication traffic should be secured as it gives access to all transfered information and might leak passwords.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Secure the network traffic using one or more technologies to provide confidentiality and integrity for the traffic, and mutual authentication for the servers.
Impact:
When the replication traffic is not secured someone might be able to capture passwords and other sensitive information when sent to the slave.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'MASTER_SSL_VERIFY_SERVER_CERT' Is Set to 'YES' or '1'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: In the MySQL SLAVE context the setting MASTER_SSL_VERIFY_SERVER_CERT indicates whether the SLAVE should verify the MASTER 's certificate. This configuration item may be set to Yes or No , and unless SSL has been enabled on the SLAVE , the value will be ignored.

controls:safeguard.title: Deploy Port-Level Access Control

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: When SSL is in use certificate verification is important to authenticate the party to which a connection is being made. In this case, the SLAVE (client) should verify the MASTER 's (server's) certificate to authenticate the MASTER prior to continuing the connection.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting you must use the CHANGE MASTER to command.
Impact:
When using CHANGE MASTER to , be aware of the following:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: SLAVE processes need to be stopped prior to executing CHANGE MASTER to .
Use of CHANGE MASTER to starts new relay logs without keeping the old ones unless explicitly told to keep them.
When CHANGE MASTER to is invoked, some information is dumped to the error log (previous values for MASTER_HOST , MASTER_PORT , MASTER_LOG_FILE , and MASTER_LOG_POS ).
Invoking CHANGE MASTER to will implicitly commit any ongoing transactions in the session where the CHANGE MASTER to was run, but not all ongoing transactions on the database.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'master_info_repository' Is Set to 'TABLE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The master_info_repository setting determines to where a slave logs master status and connection information. The options are FILE or TABLE . Note also that this setting is associated with the sync_master_info setting as well.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The password which the client uses is stored in the master info repository, which by default is a plaintext file. The TABLE master info repository is a bit safer, but with filesystem access it's still possible to gain access to the password the slave is using.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following actions to remediate this setting:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: Open the MySQL configuration file ( my.cnf )
Locate master_info_repository
Set the master_info_repository value to TABLE

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Note: If master_info_repository does not exist, add it to the configuration file.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'super_priv' is Not Set to 'Y' for Replication Users

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The SUPER privilege found in the mysql.user table governs the use of a variety of MySQL features. These features include, CHANGE MASTER TO , KILL , mysqladmin kill option, PURGE BINARY LOGS , SET GLOBAL , mysqladmin debug option, logging control, and more.

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Administrator Privileges to Dedicated Administrator Accounts
Limit Access to Script Tools

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The SUPER privilege allows principals to perform many actions, including view and terminate currently executing MySQL statements (including statements used to manage passwords). This privilege also provides the ability to configure MySQL, such as enable/disable logging, alter data, disable/enable features. Limiting the accounts that have the SUPER privilege reduces the chances that an attacker can exploit these capabilities.

When the SUPER privilege is denied to a given user, that user will be unable to take advantage of certain capabilities, such as certain mysqladmin options.
